channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: 2 Arrested in Plot to Attack Passenger Train, Canada Says
item.description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said a man arrested in Toronto and another near Montreal were working with Al Qaeda to attack a passenger train, but the public was never in “imminent danger.”
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: I.A.E.A. Says Fukushima Plant Operator Should Prepare Better
item.description: Tepco, the operator of Japan’s stricken nuclear plant, has to stop relying on stopgap measures, a team from the International Atomic Energy Agency said.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: U.S.: How the F.B.I. Trails Terrorists
item.description: The Times’s Michael Schmidt on how the F.B.I. pursues terrorism leads, like the 2011 inquiry about Tamerlan Tsarnaev.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Sondheim in Paris, With ‘Sunday in the Park’
item.description: What happens when you take a Stephen Sondheim chamber piece — “Sunday in the Park With George” — and produce it operatically, quadrupling the size of the orchestra? Mr. Sondheim talks about the show.
item.category: Sunday in the Park with George (Play)
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Nollywood: Censored at Home, Available on the Internet
item.description: The banning of “Fuelling Poverty” leaves many Nigerians questioning the government of Goodluck Jonathan.
item.dc:creator: By FRANKIE EDOZIEN
item.media:description: One of the oil price protests from 2012 in Lagos.

item.title: Visit to Japanese War Shrine Draws Anger
item.description: South Korea and China objected Monday after Japanese cabinet ministers visited a controversial war shrine.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Human Rights Watch Says Syria War Spilling Into Lebanon
item.description: A report by Human Rights Watch faulted both sides in the Syria conflict for increasing cross-border attacks.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: Foreigners Among Civilians Feared Held by Taliban
item.description: Eight Turkish engineers and at least one Russian are among the hostages after surviving a forced landing in eastern Afghanistan, officials say.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 22
item.description: Earth Day celebrated in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A boy dressed in a tree costume during Earth Day celebrations in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh. Denis Hayes, an American environmentalist coordinated the celebration of the first Earth Day in 1970 and founded the Earth Day Network.

item.title: Strike Grounds Most Lufthansa Flights
item.description: A widespread strike by ground crews and other staff all but grounded the German carrier on Monday, affecting around 150,000 passengers around the world.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Profiles in Science: Donald R. Hopkins: How to Eradicate Guinea Worm Disease
item.description: He helped eradicate smallpox, and as vice president for health programs at the Carter Center, Dr. Hopkins now has Guinea worm disease in his sights.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Donald R. Hopkins, vice president for health programs at the Carter Center, helped to eradicate smallpox and is trying to do the same to Guinea worm disease.

item.title: The Lede: April 20 Updates on Aftermath of Boston Marathon Explosions
item.description: The Lede is following the aftermath of Monday’s deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, which killed three and injured more than 170.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Red Sox fans remembered the Marathon bombing victims at Fenway Park on Saturday.

item.title: After Earthquake, Chinese Seek Out Private Charities for Their Donations
item.description: The quake that struck China last weekend has drawn a flood of donations, but those eager to donate are looking past official charity groups that now have a reputation for corruption.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: John Kerry to Host Afghans and Pakistanis
item.description: The Afghan president and a top Pakistani general will meet with the American secretary of state, John Kerry, in Brussels on Wednesday to discuss Afghan security.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: No Bunker-Buster Bomb in Israel’s U.S. Arms Deal
item.description: The Israelis said they would need such a weapon if they were to attack Iran’s underground nuclear fuel enrichment site.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: WORLD: Pakistan’s Courts Take On Musharraf
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, the once-powerful military ruler of Pakistan, is under house arrest and awaiting charges related to his time in power.

item.title: Interim Government Puts Off Musharraf Charges
item.description: Pakistan’s caretaker government declined on Monday to bring treason charges against Pervez Musharraf, saying it was beyond its mandate.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: India Ink: India Considers Banning Pornography as Reported Sexual Assault Rises
item.description: The Supreme Court is considering a petition that would make even watching pornographic material a non-bailable offense.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI and HEATHER TIMMONS
item.media:description: An internet cafe in New Delhi.

item.title: 2nd Suspect Arrested in India Child Rape
item.description: The rape of a 5-year-old girl has provoked painful questions in India, and officials are looking into other rapes of minors in New Delhi, with victims ranging in age from 2 to 15.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: An Earth Day Debate: Is There a ‘Carbon Bubble’?
item.description: A new report on the “carbon bubble” sparks front-page controversy in Britain, spurring the question, will governments ever get serious about curbing emissions?
item.category: Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: Environmental activists stage an open air carbon auction in front of the European Parliament in Brussels on April 9.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 22
item.description: Killings in Syria; outcry after rape in India; bigger cars for China; problems with carbon credits in Europe; and Sebastian Vettel on the Bahrain racetrack.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad meeting a Lebanese delegation on Sunday in a photo provided by SANA, the state news agency.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Report Says Myanmar Was Complicit in Anti-Muslim Violence
item.description: A report by a human rights group accuses Myanmar’s government of standing by, or worse, as Buddhists conducted a campaign of violence against Muslims.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered at the Shwedagon Pagoda in Yangon in June after unrest flared in the state of Rakhine, also known as Arakan, in western Myanmar.

item.title: India Ink: When Shakuntala Devi Came to America
item.description: The mathematical genius passed away on Sunday in Bangalore.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Shakuntala Devi in New Delhi on June 20, 2007.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Muddling the Legacy of Thatcher
item.description: As much as the housing crisis itself, the government's retreat over lifting restrictions on backyard construction showed just how much Britain has changed since Margaret Thatcher's era.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: More Child Rapes Being Reported In Delhi, Police Say
item.description: Five incidents in one week in April alone.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: A girl at a protest near India Gate in New Delhi on Sunday.
